Award.AwardTitle: CIF: SMALL: Circles of Trust: An Axiomatic Construction of Clustering in Asymmetric Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops an axiomatic theory of hierarchical clustering for asymmetric networks as is typical of trust propagation. Say, for example, that Miranda trusts Billy who trusts Ariel who trusts Miranda, but there has not been enough interactions in the opposite direction to establish trust. When these three people meet, shall they trust each other? The answer to this question is equivalent to the determination of whether Miranda, Billy, and Ariel are part of the same cluster: their circle of trust. The axioms of value, influence, and transformation are postulated. The Axiom of Value says that in a two-node network the nodes cluster at resolution equal to the maximum dissimilarity between them. The Axiom of Influence says that no clusters are formed at resolutions that do not allow bidirectional paths to be formed. The Axiom of Transformation states that if we consider a network and reduce all pairwise dissimilarities, the level at which two nodes become part of the same cluster is not larger than the level at which they were clustered together in the original network. Generic properties of any method that satisfies these axioms are explored and specific methods that abide by these axioms are derived. To enrich the axiomatic exploration of asymmetric clustering an application thrust and three theory thrusts are pursued. The application thrust explores the formation of circles of trust in social networks and the design of protocols to establish trust in technological networks. The theory thrusts will study alternative axiomatic formulations, stability of asymmetric hierarchical clustering algorithms, and the determination of algorithms to compute hierarchical clusters.

The educational agenda is integrated into the Market and Social Systems Engineering (MKSE) program at the University of Pennsylvania. The MKSE program is an undergraduate course of study that fully integrates the disciplines needed to design and analyze the complex networks that are reshaping our society. Given the importance of trust in these networks the research undertaken in the context of this project is incorporated into classes in the MKSE program. The excitement an idea like the formalization of trust propagation generates is further exploited to draw attention to the MKSE and Systems Engineering programs from the wider academic community. These ideas are part of a long term effort on the part of the PI to contribute to the closing of the excitement, challenge, and discipline gaps.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed an axiomatic theory of hierarchical clustering for asymmetric networks. Even though clustering, the separation of the elements of a set into equivalence classes, is a field rich with practical algorithms, its theoretical understanding remains limited. To some extent, this is because the intuitive idea of a cluster does not map all too well to the mathematical concept of partition. Hierarchical clustering methods attempt to overcome this mismatch by reporting a nested family of partitions indexed by a resolution parameter. Hierarchical clusters are tamer mathematical objects, whose theoretical underpinnings have been recently established for finite metric spaces. When we consider clustering of asymmetric data, the landscape is barren in terms of both, theory and practice. The reason for this is that intuition about clusters in asymmetric networks is difficult. E.g., if two nodes are similar in one direction but dissimilar in the other direction it is not easy to argue that they should be part of the same cluster, nor is easy to argue that they should not. There are, however, particular specks of intuition that we can leverage to gain insight into clustering of asymmetric data. This project has formalized these intuitions in the form of axioms that are used to restrict the space of admissible asymmetric hierarchical clustering methods. Methods that satisfy different axiomatic constructions were developed and studied.

An unusual ofshoopt of this proejct is a collaboration with Shakespearean scholars to analyze the authorship of plays that are either anonymous or disputed. A specific outcome of this collaboration is a paper that has been accepted for publication in Shakespeare Quarterly. This paper addresses specific issues related to the authorship of the Henry the VI trilogy. The work is unusual in that it presents the use of word adjacency networks and relative entropies in a language that targets an audience of language scholars. The paper will appear as part of an issue that addresses several questions regarding authorship and collaboration during Shakespeare’s time. This work has received sizable attention from the popular press. Reports on the addition of Christopher Marlowe as coauthor of the Henry the VI trilogy have appeared in most major news outlets.
